HED|Unrest in Egypt

20110130180007.000|20110130185949.000|SEG|Type=Story
20110130180007.000|20110130180009.000|TR0|FAREED ZAKARIA, HOST:  This is GPS, THE 
20110130180009.000|20110130180012.000|TR0|GLOBAL PUBLIC SQUARE. Welcome to all of 
20110130180012.000|20110130180015.000|TR0|you in the United States and around the 
20110130180015.000|20110130180018.000|TR0|world.  I'm Fareed Zakaria.
20110130180018.000|20110130180020.000|TR0|
20110130180020.000|20110130180023.000|TR0|We are devoting the entire show to Egypt 
20110130180023.000|20110130180026.000|TR0|today.
20110130180026.000|20110130180029.000|TR0|
20110130180029.000|20110130180032.000|TR0|Coming up in just minutes, we have an 
20110130180032.000|20110130180034.000|TR0|interview with Mohamed ElBaradei, the 
20110130180034.000|20110130180037.000|TR0|Egyptian opposition leader, Nobel 
20110130180037.000|20110130180040.000|TR0|laureate, who remains under house arrest.
20110130180040.000|20110130180043.000|TR0|
20110130180043.000|20110130180046.000|TR0|We'll check in with reporters from around 
20110130180046.000|20110130180048.000|TR0|the region for the latest.
20110130180048.000|20110130180051.000|TR0|
20110130180051.000|20110130180054.000|TR0|And we have a terrific panel of diplomats 
20110130180054.000|20110130180057.000|TR0|and scholars to put it all in context.
20110130180057.000|20110130180100.000|TR0|
20110130180100.000|20110130180102.000|TR0|Plus, an exclusive, the British Prime 
20110130180102.000|20110130180105.000|TR0|Minister David Cameron's thoughts on the 
20110130180105.000|20110130180108.000|TR0|events in Egypt.
20110130180108.000|20110130180111.000|TR0|
20110130180111.000|20110130180114.000|TR0|Now, first, let me give you my take.
20110130180114.000|20110130180116.000|TR0|
20110130180116.000|20110130180119.000|TR0|Egypt is one of the oldest countries in 
20110130180119.000|20110130180122.000|TR0|the world.  It's had roughly is same 
20110130180122.000|20110130180125.000|TR0|borders and capital city since 3,000 B.C.  
20110130180125.000|20110130180127.000|TR0|And it has always seen the embodiment of 
20110130180127.000|20110130180130.000|TR0|stability, a state ruled by pharaohs, with 
20110130180130.000|20110130180133.000|TR0|the bureaucracy that never budge.  Now, 
20110130180133.000|20110130180136.000|TR0|Egypt is in the midst of enormous change.
20110130180136.000|20110130180139.000|TR0|
20110130180139.000|20110130180141.000|TR0|This may not be a revolution in a sense of 
20110130180141.000|20110130180144.000|TR0|a massive social transformation, but it is 
20110130180144.000|20110130180147.000|TR0|a revolt.
20110130180147.000|20110130180150.000|TR0|
20110130180150.000|20110130180153.000|TR0|The first Arab revolt was in 1916 against 
20110130180153.000|20110130180155.000|TR0|the Ottoman Empire that ruled most of the 
20110130180155.000|20110130180158.000|TR0|Arab lands.  What is going on today in 
20110130180158.000|20110130180201.000|TR0|Tunisia and now Egypt is the second Arab 
20110130180201.000|20110130180204.000|TR0|revolt against the strong men who have 
20110130180204.000|20110130180207.000|TR0|ruled these lands for decades.
20110130180207.000|20110130180209.000|TR0|
20110130180209.000|20110130180212.000|TR0|Tunisia was the spark that led the fire.  
20110130180212.000|20110130180215.000|TR0|Television and the Internet and social 
20110130180215.000|20110130180218.000|TR0|media amplified and accelerated the forces 
20110130180218.000|20110130180221.000|TR0|of change.  But in a strange sense, these 
20110130180221.000|20110130180223.000|TR0|forces might have been set in motion by 
20110130180223.000|20110130180226.000|TR0|the successes of the Tunisian and Egyptian 
20110130180226.000|20110130180229.000|TR0|regimes in recent years.
20110130180229.000|20110130180232.000|TR0|
20110130180232.000|20110130180234.000|TR0|You see, Tunisia and Egypt had been 
20110130180234.000|20110130180237.000|TR0|reforming their economies. This stimulated 
20110130180237.000|20110130180240.000|TR0|growth as a consequence.  Tunisia have 
20110130180240.000|20110130180243.000|TR0|been growing at 5 percent a year and Egypt 
20110130180243.000|20110130180246.000|TR0|much faster than that.     Economic growth 
20110130180246.000|20110130180248.000|TR0|stirs up expectations.  It is this 
20110130180248.000|20110130180251.000|TR0|revolution of rising expectations that 
20110130180251.000|20110130180254.000|TR0|often undoes a dictatorship, because it is 
20110130180254.000|20110130180257.000|TR0|unable to handle the growing demands of 
20110130180257.000|20110130180300.000|TR0|its citizens.
20110130180300.000|20110130180302.000|TR0|
20110130180302.000|20110130180305.000|TR0|In Egypt, Hosni Mubarak's regime had moved 
20110130180305.000|20110130180308.000|TR0|forward economically, but actually moved 
20110130180308.000|20110130180311.000|TR0|backward politically, rigging elections, 
20110130180311.000|20110130180314.000|TR0|jailing the opposition and signaling that 
20110130180314.000|20110130180316.000|TR0|the 82-year-old ailing dictator intended 
20110130180316.000|20110130180319.000|TR0|to stay in power for years.
20110130180319.000|20110130180322.000|TR0|
20110130180322.000|20110130180325.000|TR0|What should the United States do?  Many 
20110130180325.000|20110130180328.000|TR0|journalists and intellectuals are urging 
20110130180328.000|20110130180330.000|TR0|much stronger support for the movement on 
20110130180330.000|20110130180333.000|TR0|the streets and, obviously, we are all 
20110130180333.000|20110130180336.000|TR0|thrilled by the sight and sounds of the 
20110130180336.000|20110130180339.000|TR0|people on the streets of Cairo and 
20110130180339.000|20110130180341.000|TR0|Alexandria and all over Egypt demanding 
20110130180341.000|20110130180344.000|TR0|freedom.  Everyone wants democracy and 
20110130180344.000|20110130180347.000|TR0|democracy in Egypt could be an earthquake 
20110130180347.000|20110130180350.000|TR0|in the Arab world.
20110130180350.000|20110130180353.000|TR0|
20110130180353.000|20110130180355.000|TR0|But President Obama does have to balance 
20110130180355.000|20110130180358.000|TR0|his support for democracy with the reality 
20110130180358.000|20110130180401.000|TR0|that Egypt has been a partner with America 
20110130180401.000|20110130180404.000|TR0|for over 30 years.  Imagine the 
20110130180404.000|20110130180407.000|TR0|alternative -- that the first signs of 
20110130180407.000|20110130180409.000|TR0|street protests, the U.S. unceremoniously 
20110130180409.000|20110130180412.000|TR0|dumps a stalwart ally that has made peace 
20110130180412.000|20110130180415.000|TR0|with Israel, fought al-Qaeda, tried to 
20110130180415.000|20110130180418.000|TR0|moderate Hamas and brokered deals for the 
20110130180418.000|20110130180421.000|TR0|Palestinians.
20110130180421.000|20110130180423.000|TR0|
20110130180423.000|20110130180426.000|TR0|My solution would be that President Obama 
20110130180426.000|20110130180429.000|TR0|clearly and firmly, but privately, tell 
20110130180429.000|20110130180432.000|TR0|President Mubarak that he must resign, 
20110130180432.000|20110130180435.000|TR0|perhaps not immediately, but soon.  His 
20110130180435.000|20110130180437.000|TR0|vice president must organize a new 
20110130180437.000|20110130180440.000|TR0|constitutional body to write a 
20110130180440.000|20110130180443.000|TR0|constitution for Egypt, with strong 
20110130180443.000|20110130180446.000|TR0|protections for individual rights, 
20110130180446.000|20110130180448.000|TR0|minority interests, freedom of the press, 
20110130180448.000|20110130180451.000|TR0|and then carefully set up a process for 
20110130180451.000|20110130180454.000|TR0|national elections.
20110130180454.000|20110130180457.000|TR0|
20110130180457.000|20110130180500.000|TR0|Obama does not need to call publicly for 
20110130180500.000|20110130180502.000|TR0|Mubarak's resignation, but he does need to 
20110130180502.000|20110130180505.000|TR0|get him to go.  America has been urging 
20110130180505.000|20110130180508.000|TR0|the Egyptian regime to reform for years, 
20110130180508.000|20110130180511.000|TR0|even decades.  Hosni Mubarak never took 
20110130180511.000|20110130180514.000|TR0|these calls seriously.  Had he done so, 
20110130180514.000|20110130180516.000|TR0|had he come out in front of these changes, 
20110130180516.000|20110130180519.000|TR0|had he come out in front of his people, he 
20110130180519.000|20110130180522.000|TR0|could have avoided this revolt.  But that 
20110130180522.000|20110130180525.000|TR0|is the story of dictators. It is often too 
20110130180525.000|20110130180528.000|TR0|little too late.
20110130180528.000|20110130180530.000|TR0|
20110130180530.000|20110130180533.000|TR0|Let's get started.
20110130180533.000|20110130180536.000|TR0|
20110130180536.000|20110130180539.000|TR0|(MUSIC)

20110130180542.000|20110130180544.000|TR0|ZAKARIA:  Mohamed ElBaradei is, perhaps 
20110130180544.000|20110130180547.000|TR0|after President Mubarak, the crucial 
20110130180547.000|20110130180550.000|TR0|figure in this story.  After his leaving 
20110130180550.000|20110130180553.000|TR0|his post as head of the world's nuclear 
20110130180553.000|20110130180555.000|TR0|watchdog, the International Atomic Energy 
20110130180555.000|20110130180558.000|TR0|Agency, he has devoted himself to 
20110130180558.000|20110130180601.000|TR0|agitating for change in Egypt, his home 
20110130180601.000|20110130180604.000|TR0|country.  And how he is the most 
20110130180604.000|20110130180607.000|TR0|high-profile leader of the opposition 
20110130180607.000|20110130180609.000|TR0|movement in Egypt.
20110130180609.000|20110130180612.000|TR0|
20110130180612.000|20110130180615.000|TR0|He was put under house arrest on Friday, 
20110130180615.000|20110130180618.000|TR0|but is able to join me now from his home 
20110130180618.000|20110130180621.000|TR0|in Cairo.  Thank you for joining us, 
20110130180621.000|20110130180623.000|TR0|Mohamed ElBaradei.
20110130180623.000|20110130180626.000|TR0|
20110130180626.000|20110130180629.000|TR0|MOHAMED ELBARADEI, FORMER IAEA DIRECTOR:  
20110130180629.000|20110130180632.000|TR0|It's always a pleasure to be with you, 
20110130180632.000|20110130180635.000|TR0|Fareed.     ZAKARIA:  Mohamed, what do you 
20110130180635.000|20110130180637.000|TR0|make of the most recent moves by President 
20110130180637.000|20110130180640.000|TR0|Mubarak, appointing Omar Suleiman as his 
20110130180640.000|20110130180643.000|TR0|vice president, appointing another former 
20110130180643.000|20110130180646.000|TR0|army officer as the prime minister, the 
20110130180646.000|20110130180649.000|TR0|former aviation minister.  What is your 
20110130180649.000|20110130180651.000|TR0|reaction?
20110130180651.000|20110130180654.000|TR0|
20110130180654.000|20110130180657.000|TR0|ELBARADEI:  Well, Fareed, I think this is 
20110130180657.000|20110130180700.000|TR0|hopeless, desperate attempts by Mubarak to 
20110130180700.000|20110130180702.000|TR0|stay in power.  I think it is loud and 
20110130180702.000|20110130180705.000|TR0|clear from everybody in Egypt that Mubarak 
20110130180705.000|20110130180708.000|TR0|has to leave today, and it is 
20110130180708.000|20110130180711.000|TR0|non-negotiable for every Egyptian.  People 
20110130180711.000|20110130180714.000|TR0|have been saying or demonstrating for his 
20110130180714.000|20110130180716.000|TR0|-- for him to leave.  Today, the 
20110130180716.000|20110130180719.000|TR0|demonstrations say that he should be put 
20110130180719.000|20110130180722.000|TR0|to trial.  If he wants to save his skin, 
20110130180722.000|20110130180725.000|TR0|if he has an iota of patriotism, I would 
20110130180725.000|20110130180728.000|TR0|advise him to leave today and save the 
20110130180728.000|20110130180730.000|TR0|country.
20110130180730.000|20110130180733.000|TR0|
20110130180733.000|20110130180736.000|TR0|ZAKARIA:  And what would you like to see 
20110130180736.000|20110130180739.000|TR0|happen after that?  Let us say Mubarak 
20110130180739.000|20110130180742.000|TR0|resigns.  What is the -- what are the next 
20110130180742.000|20110130180744.000|TR0|steps that must happen in Egypt?
20110130180744.000|20110130180747.000|TR0|
20110130180747.000|20110130180750.000|TR0|ELBARADEI:  Well, the next step, Fareed, 
20110130180750.000|20110130180753.000|TR0|as everybody now agrees on, is a 
20110130180753.000|20110130180756.000|TR0|transitional period, a government of 
20110130180756.000|20110130180758.000|TR0|national salvation, of national unity, and 
20110130180758.000|20110130180801.000|TR0|that will prepare the ground for a new 
20110130180801.000|20110130180804.000|TR0|constitution, free and fair election.  
20110130180804.000|20110130180807.000|TR0|These are the three basic demands, what 
20110130180807.000|20110130180809.000|TR0|every Egyptian is agreeing upon.  And of 
20110130180809.000|20110130180812.000|TR0|course, you know, hoping that the army 
20110130180812.000|20110130180815.000|TR0|will be able to control the situation.
20110130180815.000|20110130180818.000|TR0|
20110130180818.000|20110130180821.000|TR0|Right now, Fareed, the country is ablaze.  
20110130180821.000|20110130180823.000|TR0|Looting is everywhere. Disbanded police 
20110130180823.000|20110130180826.000|TR0|forces that were disbanded for -- nobody 
20110130180826.000|20110130180829.000|TR0|knows how they were disbanded -- are 
20110130180829.000|20110130180832.000|TR0|looting around the country.  The army is 
20110130180832.000|20110130180835.000|TR0|not able to control things.  Millions are 
20110130180835.000|20110130180837.000|TR0|in the streets.  This is a country that's 
20110130180837.000|20110130180840.000|TR0|falling apart, and the -- he needs to 
20110130180840.000|20110130180843.000|TR0|leave today. That will hope help (ph), at 
20110130180843.000|20110130180846.000|TR0|least 70 percent, to be followed by a 
20110130180846.000|20110130180849.000|TR0|smooth transition of a national unity 
20110130180849.000|20110130180851.000|TR0|government, to be followed by all the 
20110130180851.000|20110130180854.000|TR0|measures set in place for a free and fair 
20110130180854.000|20110130180857.000|TR0|election and democratic constitution.
20110130180857.000|20110130180900.000|TR0|
20110130180900.000|20110130180903.000|TR0|Egypt needs to catch up with the rest of 
20110130180903.000|20110130180905.000|TR0|the world.  We need to be free, 
20110130180905.000|20110130180908.000|TR0|democratic, and -- society where people 
20110130180908.000|20110130180911.000|TR0|have the right to live in freedom and 
20110130180911.000|20110130180914.000|TR0|dignity.  That's what you get after 30 
20110130180914.000|20110130180917.000|TR0|years, Fareed, of utter brutal 
20110130180917.000|20110130180919.000|TR0|dictatorship supported by everybody in the 
20110130180919.000|20110130180922.000|TR0|name of pseudo-stability.
20110130180922.000|20110130180925.000|TR0|
20110130180925.000|20110130180928.000|TR0|ZAKARIA:  You mention the army, Mohamed.  
20110130180928.000|20110130180930.000|TR0|Talk about that, because Omar Suleiman is 
20110130180930.000|20110130180933.000|TR0|himself a former -- a member of the armed 
20110130180933.000|20110130180936.000|TR0|forces.  The new prime minister is.  There 
20110130180936.000|20110130180939.000|TR0|is speculation that the army is backing 
20110130180939.000|20110130180942.000|TR0|these moves by Mubarak and has in effect 
20110130180942.000|20110130180944.000|TR0|taken control of the country.
20110130180944.000|20110130180947.000|TR0|
20110130180947.000|20110130180950.000|TR0|ELBARADEI:  Well, I don't think that the 
20110130180950.000|20110130180953.000|TR0|army has taken control of the country, 
20110130180953.000|20110130180956.000|TR0|Fareed.  If you -- if you look around, 
20110130180956.000|20110130180958.000|TR0|there's half million people everywhere, in 
20110130180958.000|20110130181001.000|TR0|the middle of Cairo, in the middle of 
20110130181001.000|20110130181004.000|TR0|Alexandria.
20110130181004.000|20110130181007.000|TR0|
20110130181007.000|20110130181010.000|TR0|Omar Suleiman is a person I know.  I have 
20110130181010.000|20110130181012.000|TR0|respect for him.  But the army is 
20110130181012.000|20110130181015.000|TR0|(inaudible) not change of personalities.  
20110130181015.000|20110130181018.000|TR0|We need a change of system.  We need to 
20110130181018.000|20110130181021.000|TR0|have substantive, drastic shifts from a 
20110130181021.000|20110130181024.000|TR0|dictatorship into a democracy, like the 
20110130181024.000|20110130181026.000|TR0|rest of the world.      What I have been 
20110130181026.000|20110130181029.000|TR0|authorized, mandated by the people who 
20110130181029.000|20110130181032.000|TR0|organized these demonstrations and by many 
20110130181032.000|20110130181035.000|TR0|other parts of the Egyptians, to agree on 
20110130181035.000|20110130181037.000|TR0|a national unity government.  And I hope 
20110130181037.000|20110130181040.000|TR0|that I would -- I should be in touch soon 
20110130181040.000|20110130181043.000|TR0|with the army, and we need to work 
20110130181043.000|20110130181046.000|TR0|together. The army is part of Egypt, and 
20110130181046.000|20110130181049.000|TR0|we have the highest respect for them as 
20110130181049.000|20110130181051.000|TR0|civilians, and we need to work together to 
20110130181051.000|20110130181054.000|TR0|get Egypt (inaudible).
20110130181054.000|20110130181057.000|TR0|
20110130181057.000|20110130181100.000|TR0|What do we have today?  A country that's 
20110130181100.000|20110130181103.000|TR0|falling apart.
20110130181103.000|20110130181105.000|TR0|
20110130181105.000|20110130181108.000|TR0|ZAKARIA:  You say you are -- you hope to 
20110130181108.000|20110130181111.000|TR0|be in contact with the army.  Have they 
20110130181111.000|20110130181114.000|TR0|reached out to you?  Do you intend to 
20110130181114.000|20110130181117.000|TR0|reach out to them?
20110130181117.000|20110130181119.000|TR0|
20110130181119.000|20110130181122.000|TR0|ELBARADEI:  Not yet, Fareed.  I haven't.  
20110130181122.000|20110130181125.000|TR0|I mean, the whole situation has been 
20110130181125.000|20110130181128.000|TR0|moving very, very fast, and -- but today 
20110130181128.000|20110130181131.000|TR0|there has been a number of declarations by 
20110130181131.000|20110130181133.000|TR0|different parts of the Egyptian society, 
20110130181133.000|20110130181136.000|TR0|from right, left and center, mandating me 
20110130181136.000|20110130181139.000|TR0|to work in -- with them, with the army, 
20110130181139.000|20110130181142.000|TR0|with everybody in Egypt, with outside 
20110130181142.000|20110130181144.000|TR0|world, to ensure smooth transition.
20110130181144.000|20110130181147.000|TR0|
20110130181147.000|20110130181150.000|TR0|ZAKARIA:  You've heard President Obama's 
20110130181150.000|20110130181153.000|TR0|statements in which he says he has asked 
20110130181153.000|20110130181156.000|TR0|President Mubarak to act on his promise to 
20110130181156.000|20110130181158.000|TR0|change, to bring democracy to Egypt.  Do 
20110130181158.000|20110130181201.000|TR0|you think -- do you want him to do more 
20110130181201.000|20110130181204.000|TR0|than that?
20110130181204.000|20110130181207.000|TR0|
20110130181207.000|20110130181210.000|TR0|ELBARADEI:  Of course I do.  I have, as 
20110130181210.000|20110130181212.000|TR0|you know, the utmost respect for President 
20110130181212.000|20110130181215.000|TR0|Obama as a person.  I worked with him 
20110130181215.000|20110130181218.000|TR0|during my time at the IAEA.  I have a lot 
20110130181218.000|20110130181221.000|TR0|of admiration for him.  But I can tell 
20110130181221.000|20110130181224.000|TR0|you, honestly, as a friend of the U.S., 
20110130181224.000|20110130181226.000|TR0|that your policy right now is a failed 
20110130181226.000|20110130181229.000|TR0|policy, is a policy that is lagging 
20110130181229.000|20110130181232.000|TR0|behind, is a policy that is -- is -- 
20110130181232.000|20110130181235.000|TR0|having the effect here in Egypt that you 
20110130181235.000|20110130181238.000|TR0|are losing whatever left of credibility.
20110130181238.000|20110130181240.000|TR0|
20110130181240.000|20110130181243.000|TR0|And -- however, this is -- this has been

20110130182511.000|20110130182514.000|TR0|thugs that the regime used to rely on to 
20110130182514.000|20110130182517.000|TR0|crack down people during elections.  
20110130182517.000|20110130182520.000|TR0|They've let them loose.  They've opened up 
20110130182520.000|20110130182522.000|TR0|the prisons and allowed criminals to roam

20110130182536.000|20110130182539.000|TR0|Egyptians, OK, if you want to protest this

20110130182556.000|20110130182559.000|TR0|will work.     ZAKARIA:  Richard Haass, 
20110130182559.000|20110130182602.000|TR0|what should the army do?  Because this is

20110130183647.000|20110130183649.000|TR0|It's the sort of thing history shows from 
20110130183649.000|20110130183652.000|TR0|other parts of the world, historically, 
20110130183652.000|20110130183655.000|TR0|over the last few centuries, you're much 
20110130183655.000|20110130183658.000|TR0|wiser to push gradually for political 
20110130183658.000|20110130183700.000|TR0|change when things are calm.  If you wait 
20110130183700.000|20110130183703.000|TR0|until the people are in the streets, be 
20110130183703.000|20110130183706.000|TR0|careful. You feed the beast.  And it's not 
20110130183706.000|20110130183709.000|TR0|clear that at the end of the day, you will 
20110130183709.000|20110130183712.000|TR0|set into motion a set of events you can 
20110130183712.000|20110130183714.000|TR0|control.
20110130183714.000|20110130183717.000|TR0|
20110130183717.000|20110130183720.000|TR0|There are alternatives that are worse to 
20110130183720.000|20110130183723.000|TR0|Hosni Mubarak and the status quo.  Doesn't

20110130184709.000|20110130184712.000|TR0|

20110130184715.000|20110130184717.000|TR0|in the past, sometimes we in the West have 
20110130184717.000|20110130184720.000|TR0|taken rather a simple view that what 
20110130184720.000|20110130184723.000|TR0|matters is just the act of holding an 
20110130184723.000|20110130184726.000|TR0|election.  Real democracy is actually 
20110130184726.000|20110130184729.000|TR0|about the building blocks you put in 
20110130184729.000|20110130184731.000|TR0|place, about the rule of law, the rights,

20110130184734.000|20110130184737.000|TR0|freedoms you have in that country.

20110130184743.000|20110130184745.000|TR0|and thoughtful approach to these countries 
20110130184745.000|20110130184748.000|TR0|and recognize it's those building blocks 
20110130184748.000|20110130184751.000|TR0|that, in the end, make your country 
20110130184751.000|20110130184754.000|TR0|democratic, strong, accountable, all the 
20110130184754.000|20110130184757.000|TR0|things we believe in the West, rather than 
20110130184757.000|20110130184759.000|TR0|simply believing democracy is just the act

20110130184802.000|20110130184805.000|TR0|

20110130184811.000|20110130184813.000|TR0|America.  And we need to apply that

20110130184912.000|20110130184915.000|TR0|it that way.     ZAKARIA:  Is Mubarak a 
20110130184915.000|20110130184918.000|TR0|friend of Britain?

20110130184920.000|20110130184923.000|TR0|CAMERON:  He is a friend of Britain.  
20110130184923.000|20110130184926.000|TR0|Britain has good relations with Egypt.  
20110130184926.000|20110130184929.000|TR0|We've worked together over many issues 
20110130184929.000|20110130184931.000|TR0|that cause concern, not least the Middle 
20110130184931.000|20110130184934.000|TR0|East, where we want to see progress, not

20110130184937.000|20110130184940.000|TR0|extremism.  And as I say, in those 
20110130184940.000|20110130184943.000|TR0|countries, particularly those countries 
20110130184943.000|20110130184945.000|TR0|that have potential problems in terms of 
20110130184945.000|20110130184948.000|TR0|Islamic extremism, it seems to me the 
20110130184948.000|20110130184951.000|TR0|building blocks of democracy -- the 
20110130184951.000|20110130184954.000|TR0|rights, the rule of law, the independence 
20110130184954.000|20110130184957.000|TR0|of the judiciary, making sure the army 
20110130184957.000|20110130184959.000|TR0|plays a proper role in society -- those 
20110130184959.000|20110130185002.000|TR0|building blocks are even more important in 
20110130185002.000|20110130185005.000|TR0|countries prey to Islamic extremism, and 
20110130185005.000|20110130185008.000|TR0|in other countries.
20110130185008.000|20110130185011.000|TR0|
20110130185011.000|20110130185013.000|TR0|But frankly, they're essential to all 
20110130185013.000|20110130185016.000|TR0|countries, and it's those building blocks 
20110130185016.000|20110130185019.000|TR0|that I think we should focus on.  And in 
20110130185019.000|20110130185022.000|TR0|the relations we've had with Egypt, we've
